Award.AwardTitle: Encouraging the use of Evidence-Based Instructional Practices through Research Initiatives: An assessment of university climate

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is for a WIDER program planning grant. The purpose of this planning grant is to identify the current usage of evidence-based instructional practices and the balance between restricting and driving influences for their implementation at Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University (ERAU) using the Transtheoretical Model for Health Behavior Change. Not previously applied to education, this model acknowledges that change can be cyclic and include relapses to a previous state, similar to findings from research into diffusion of education innovations and use of signature pedagogies in STEM education. The model is being used to guide the collection of mixed-methods data from faculty in the College of Engineering and College of Arts and Science that teach first-year general education STEM courses in the engineering curriculum. Data are being analyzed to identify evidence-based instructional practices currently used by these faculty, distribution of stages of change, processes used to advance through the stages of change, and the balance between the magnitude of driving and restricting forces.

The outcomes of this project will be used to provide a guide to develop interventions, based on specific independent variables associated with each individual faculty member in general education mathematics, physical sciences, and engineering courses, encouraging use of evidence-based instructional practices. The inventory of evidence-based instructional practices currently implemented at ERAU collected through this planning grant will allow ERAU's Center of Teaching and Learning Excellence to utilize appropriate faculty activities with respect to particular stages of change. The analysis will also result in a plan to encourage driving forces and limit restricting forces, shifting the balance towards a progressive stance on the implementation of evidence-based instructional practices. The enhanced use of these practices, especially beneficial to underrepresented groups, encourages student learning in first year engineering courses that is expected to reduce student attrition at ERAU. Dissemination of the findings of this project will provide other institutions with a plan to apply the Transtheoretical Model of Health Behavior Change and associated analyses to assess faculty use of evidence-based practices at their institution, as well as to increase the likelihood of adoption of those practices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this planning grant is to identify the current usage of evidence-based instructional practices (EBIPs), identify the processes used to advance through stages of implementation, and assess the driving and restricting forces that impact their implementation in foundational Science, Mathematics, Engineering Fundamentals, and Engineering Sciences courses primarily taken by engineering students in the first two years of their undergraduate curriculum at Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University (ERAU). EBIP usage was examined through the lens of the Trans-Theoretical Model of Behavior Change (TTM).

Over the duration of the grant, a total of 54 faculty who taught foundational STEM courses in Engineering Fundamentals (31%), Engineering Sciences (13%), Mathematics (28%), and Physical Sciences (28%) were interviewed on their usage of the specified evidence-based instructional practices and the respective driving and restricting forces. Additionally, each of the 54 faculty had a standard class session video recorded. A survey was also distributed to all faculty in these departments and colleges which received a cumulative 61% response rate. Analyses included identification of stage of change for each EBIP, characterization of the EBIP based on high and low fidelity implementations, and the identification of misconceptions for that EBIP.  Thematic analysis characterized and described driving and restricting forces which informed the survey used to generate an overall force-field analysis to identify the balance between driving and restricting forces. Interview responses, survey responses, and classroom observations were also analyzed for variations based on course context (department) and faculty characteristics, including faculty involvement in research.

Across the course contexts examined, Active Learning and Collaborative/Cooperative Learning were identified to be the most familiar and implemented techniques in their respective courses. Faculty participants were less familiar with Just-in-Time Teaching and frequently had misconceptions regarding the use of Inquiry Learning and Peer Instruction/Concept Tests. Triangulation of the data estimates that between 70% and 80% of faculty who teach foundational STEM courses in the engineering curriculum use some form of Active or Collaborative Learning, most commonly implemented by having students, individually or in groups, solve analytical problems with the facilitation of the instructor.

Comparing across departmental contexts, Engineering Sciences, Mathematics, and Physical Science courses use similar pedagogical approaches that center around lecturing while writing with the inclusion of some problem solving activities, whereas Engineering Fundamentals utilizes a balanced approach that applies more Active Learning facilitated by individualized instruction. Variations in implementation were identified across faculty characteristics. Specifically, women were more likely to implement techniques associated with Peering Instruction/Concept Tests and Think-Pair-Share. Whereas, tenured faculty were less likely to implement Inquiry Learning.

The processes used to advance through the stages of implementation for any evidence-based instructional practice primarily included consciousness raising, environmental reevaluation, and counter conditioning. Stimulus control was effective in maintaining the use of any EBIP and was accomplished through the standardization of lesson plans, assignments, and classroom layout where deviation from the use of the EBIP was perceived to be more difficult than reverting back to traditional forms of lecture-based instruction.

Force-field analysis of faculty participants identified a positive balance towards the implementation of EBIPs; aligning with findings from faculty usage of the techniques. Prominent driving forces include increasing student engagement in class, increasing student knowledge of content, developing students into self-directed learners, and providing formative feedback to faculty on student understandings of content. Restricting forces included a lack of class time to cover content, non-participating students, class distractions, classroom management, and affective perceptions of student capabilities.

Despite a current university focus on the inclusion of research into faculty workload, very little difference was identified between faculty who were actively engaged in research and those that had no research responsibilities. In general, faculty participants do not perceive that the use of those techniques are discourage in order to place more emphasis on research. Instead, the inclusion of research only adds to the overall workload, where research faculty are limited in their time to develop and implement the techniques.  Research active faculty saw the inclusion of research into their class as a driving force to contextualize the content and integrate Inquiry Learning in their course.

A detailed report of findings and sample video examples of evidence-based instructional practices have been posted on the local Center of Teaching and Learning Excellence (CTLE) resource webpage for access to all ERAU faculty. Reports have also been provided to the respective Department Chairs and Deans of courses involved in this study. The PI team has presented findings to CTLE and the Task Force on Innovation and ongoing efforts are providing empirical data to these groups for planning purposes to encourage the usage of evidence-based instructional practices across the entire Daytona Beach campus. This study provides the STEM Education community a framework to evaluate stage of pedagogical change for faculty, the driving and restricting forces affecting that change, and insight into actionable process to advance faculty through the stages.
